caseTitle: RICHARD OSAE DUODU VRS NANA AMA BENEWAH
summary: This is a civil land dispute appeal before the Supreme Court of Ghana, where Richard Osae Duodu (plaintiff/appellant) challenged the Court of Appeal's reversal of the High Court’s judgment in his favor. The dispute centered on ownership of a parcel of land in Accra, with both parties claiming title through separate purchases from the Reindorf family. The defendant, Nana Ama Benewah, alleged that the plaintiff’s grantor forged the signature of Carl Reindorf, the family representative, in the deed of assignment (Exhibit A). A forensic expert confirmed the forgery, and the Court of Appeal found the plaintiff’s title tainted by fraud. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal’s decision, ruling that the plaintiff failed to discharge the burden of proving he was a bona fide purchaser for value without notice, especially given the clear evidence of fraud that a diligent buyer should have detected. The appeal was dismissed, and the defendant’s claim to title was affirmed.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; judgment of the Court of Appeal upheld.
citations: ACKA V PERGAH TRANSPORT LTD [2010] SCGLR 728
OBENG V ASSEMBLIES OF GOD CHURCH, GHANA [2010] SCGLR 300
PILCHER V RAWLINS [1871-72] 7 LR Ch App 259
rationaleHighlights: Fraud was conclusively established through forensic evidence and oral testimony.
The appellant failed to prove the plea of being a bona fide purchaser for value without notice.
The trial judge erred in granting title despite proven fraud, which vitiates all transactions.
Appellate courts have the duty to review evidence where no concurrent findings exist.
The burden of proving bona fides lies with the party asserting it.
A prudent purchaser should have discovered the forgery during due diligence.
The Court of Appeal correctly reversed the High Court's judgment.
Damages were justified due to denial of possession.
